title: Thung Phaya Thai
text:
Thung Phaya Thai (, ) is a "<a href="khwaeng">khwaeng</a>" (subdistrict) of <a href="Ratchathewi">Ratchathewi</a> District, downtown <a href="Bangkok">Bangkok</a>.
History.
This area formerly known as "Thung Phaya Thai", a vast field in the area of inner capital, it covers the area from the outskirts of <a href="Dusit%20Palace">Dusit Palace</a> next to the Thung Som Poi (now is the location of <a href="Chitralada%20Royal%20Villa">Chitralada Royal Villa</a>) to the <a href="Victory%20Monument%2C%20Bangkok">Victory Monument</a> and <a href="Phaya%20Thai%20Palace">Phaya Thai Palace</a> today. The next area was known as "Thung Bang Kapi" of <a href="Bang%20Kapi">Bang Kapi</a> and <a href="Wang%20Thonglang">Wang Thonglang</a> with <a href="Huai%20Khwang">Huai Khwang</a> Districts in present day.
Although it was an inner city area, but the atmosphere in the past, it was a rural <a href="countryside">countryside</a> and fresh air. Khlong Phaya Thai, a "<a href="khlong">khlong</a>" (canal) which was approximately two km (1.24 mi) long, flows through the area.
Therefore, King <a href="Rama%20V">Rama V</a> bought more than a thousand "<a href="rai%20%28unit%29">rai</a>" (more than 395 <a href="acre">acre</a>s) of land here. He ordered the construction of Phaya Thai Palace in 1910 along the banks of Khlong Samsen, as well as having to build a road connecting Hua Lamphong Road (now <a href="Rama%20IV%20Road">Rama IV Road</a>), pass Pathum Wan Road (now <a href="Rama%20I%20Road">Rama I Road</a>), parallel to Pra Chae Chin Road (now <a href="Phetchaburi%20Road">Phetchaburi Road</a>), cuts across <a href="Eastern%20Line%20%28Thailand%29">eastern railway line</a> and Duang Tawan Road (now <a href="Si%20Ayutthaya%20Road">Si Ayutthaya Road</a>), as far as ending at Pao Road (now <a href="Phahonyothin%20Road">Phahonyothin Road</a>), called "<a href="Phaya%20Thai%20Road">Phaya Thai Road</a>".
The king and his wife, Queen <a href="Saovabha%20Phongsri">Saovabha Phongsri</a> used the palace as a royal retreat, and the king used this place to test the cultivation as well.
In addition, in those days, this palace was also used as a place to hold up to the <a href="Royal%20Ploughing%20Ceremony">Royal Ploughing Ceremony</a>, which was a ceremony that has existed since ancient times to give the morale to farmers in the beginning of the planting season. After King Rama V passed away in 1910, Queen Saovabha Phongsri used this place as a residence until she died in 1919.
This area was also residence to <a href="Islam%20in%20Thailand">Muslim</a>s as well.
Currently, although the fields have disappeared, Khlong Phaya Thai was filled in to allow the road to be built, until it became just a small waterway in <a href="Phramongkutklao%20Hospital">Phramongkutklao Hospital</a>, but the name "Thung Phaya Thai" is still used for this area, and due to the numerous modifications of <a href="Bangkok%20Metropolitan%20Administration">Bangkok administration</a> making Thung Phaya Thai become part of Ratchathewi District to the present.
Geography.
The area is bordered by neighbouring subdistricts (from north clockwise): Phaya Thai and, Sam Sen Nai in <a href="Phaya%20Thai%20District">Phaya Thai</a> District (Khlong Sam Sen is a borderline), <a href="Makkasan">Makkasan</a>, and Thanon Phetchaburi in its district (Phaya Thai Road and Si Ayutthaya Road are the borderlines), <a href="Suan%20Chitlada">Suan Chitlada</a> in <a href="Dusit%20District">Dusit</a> District (<a href="Northern%20Line%20%28Thailand%29">Northern Railway Line</a> is a borderline).
